title: 110_hr1407
content: The Act titled "Higher Education Affordability and Equity Act of 2007" expands the deduction for interest on education loans. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal the dollar limitation and increase the phaseout beginning point for deductions based on modified adjusted gross income. The deduction amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for single and joint filers. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to repeal the dollar limitation and increase the phaseout beginning point for deductions based on modified adjusted gross income. The deduction amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's modified adjusted gross income, with specific thresholds for single and joint filers. In the case of a taxable year beginning after 2008, the $100,000 and $200,000 amounts in subsection (b) shall each be increased by an amount equal to the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. The deduction amounts for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007, shall be increased by the cost-of-living adjustment determined for the calendar year. SEC. 3 makes the deduction for qualified tuition and related expenses permanent, with an effective date for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 4 increases allowable contributions for education savings accounts to $5,000 and adjusts reporting requirements, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 5 allows for room, board, and special needs services to be included in scholarships and tuition reduction programs for higher education. In amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, qualified scholarship definitions are expanded to include qualified higher education expenses for enrollment at eligible educational institutions. Additionally, terms like 'qualified higher education expenses' and 'eligible educational institution' are defined in section 529(e). Special rules for teaching and research assistants are also modified to remove restrictions below the graduate level. The amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 expand qualified scholarship definitions to include qualified higher education expenses at eligible educational institutions. Special rules for teaching and research assistants are modified to remove restrictions below the graduate level and substitute 'qualified higher education expenses' for 'tuition' in certain instances. Effective December 31, 2007, these amendments apply to expenses for education in academic periods after that date. Expansion of educational expenses allowed as part of Hope Scholarship Credit. Expansion of qualified tuition and related expenses for the Hope Scholarship Credit to include fees, books, supplies, and equipment required for courses at eligible educational institutions. The Hope Scholarship Credit will not be reduced by Federal Pell Grants or Supplemental Educational Opportunity Grants. The amendments expand qualified tuition expenses for the Hope Scholarship Credit to include fees, books, supplies, and equipment. Pell and SEOG grants will not reduce the credit. Expenses paid after December 31, 2007, for education after that date are affected. Title IX of the Economic Growth and Tax Relief Reconciliation Act of 2001 exempts certain education provisions from the sunset clause, specifically subtitles A, B, and D of title IV.
